instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U5110: What is U5110? This chip is responsible for SMC_RESET_L in many Macbook models..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green Light
threads.message:
Had liquid damage, mostly over the LVDS etc area. Ultrasonic, no green light.

PPBUS - 8.2v
PP3v42 - 3.42v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 0.1v

Tried SMC reflow, same result. Tried reball, no dice. New SMC, same result. 2nd smc replacement, nothing. Don't wanna fuck with <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> or <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> quite yet. Anything else it could be? Or possibly three dead SMCs?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green Light
threads.message: The first thing you should have fucked with was <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> and/or <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR>!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green Light
threads.message: Just read your comment, yeah I tried that tonight as well. <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> reads at 94k and replaced <CHIP>U5110</CHIP>. Still no dice :\ Could be a bad one, will try again tomorrow.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green Light
threads.message: You prob only had a <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> problem to begin with. If you still have the original SMC, try and put it back with a new <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> if the original SMC isn't dead from being heated/reballed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green Light
threads.message: I'm at a loss here, unless I have a bunch of bad SMC's (ive replaced a ton before, never killed them from heat) I have no clue where to look next. <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> reads at 3.3v so not sure if that could be an issue... Is <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> not turning on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green Light
threads.message: What is your voltage on <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>? If it's not 3.4 then you have an issue with the <CHIP>U5110</CHIP> chip...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green Light
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No Green Light
threads.message: Sorry duke, never got a chance to measure. Finally replaced it with a known good SMC (off a board I was planning on using in the future) and it greenlighted. I guess I just had dead SMC's. Computer needs a new battery, new keyboard, new trackpad, new LCD, and board repair. Customer is going to buy a new computer. SOOOOOOO all that effort was for nothing. Transfered the SMC back to the working board and it still works perfectly. I was getting so mad at the other SMC's
